Posts.Content: On 12/6/2007 louiseUK wrote: I'd really appreciate some advice please. My mother has just been diagnosed with breast cancer. Her sister, father, two aunts, a cousin and grand-mother all died from breast cancer, most of them in their 40s. My sister and I have been told we must have gene tests etc. My sister, is refusing to do so, saying she'd rather not know. I have a totally different view. (I'm 31, by the way).  It has been suggested to me that I should consider having an elective double mastectomy. Without wishing to sound flippant, I am quite keen on the idea. Looking at my family history, things don't bode well for me and prevention is better than cure etc. I'd be grateful if you would let me know what you think. It would really help me :-)  Many thanks, Louise Be sure to get genetic testing before you consider a double mastectomy; and read the book Apron Strings by Diane Tropea Greene.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: Elective double mastectomy

Posts.Content: Thanks for the encouraging words.  My hair is just starting to fall out, 3 days after my second chemo treatment, which is about 17 days after my first treatment.   I made an appointment to have my head shaved tomorrow.  I'll have a friend hold my hand and I will not look in the mirror.  I'll bring my lovely wig (just like my own hair) with me for the hairdresser to put on.  In addition, I plan to wear some kibnd of head covering on my head while at home.  I don't think I can stand looking at my bald head!!  Yes, I am trying to stay positive.  Good luck to you too. On 6/13/2007 Mother of Twins wrote: when i started chemo for breast cancer i had a very helpful lady who ran a wig store and also had been through breast cancer.  you have 10 to 12 days before you hair starts to fall out.  mine started on day 12 after your first round of chemo.  the drug that causes it is what they call the "red devil"  i had fun with my hair loss, my hair was dark and very curly so i decided to go straigh and auburn.  actually a lot of people liked the wig more than my hair.  you have to do this and your emotional health has a lot to do with your recovery so be positive and try different things.  i also had a purple/pink tied dyed bandana i enjoyed wearing also.  then after a couple of treatments i just decided to answer my door with nothing on my head.  now days when they see a woman bald they will automatically think chemo for breast cancer.  if all else fails, draw a pink ribbon on top of your head.  i do hope you do well and stay positive.

Posts.Content: Does caffeine (coffee or tea) have any effect on breast cancer- like possibly cause for recurrence?  This is already my second diagnosis.  I had a double mastectomy, then reconstructive surgery, then chemo.  Now I'm in the middle of radiation treatments.  Should I avoid caffeine altogether, including chocolate, or is there only minimal effect now?
